moves.1. d4: Because I know the e4 and d4 open I know the proper response according to what I learned from the 1960's when Fischer and Spassky were at it...
moves.1... Nf6: I like the Nimzo Attack by you know who. I also like King's Indian Defense.
moves.2... e6: I go for the NIMZO ATTACK instead of the King's Indian. Either will do.
moves.3... Bb4: The Nimzo Attack. I learned this as an attack and not a defense. I learned it in the 60's against White. Today they call it a Defense; however, in my days it was an attack.
moves.4. e3:
White is willing to suffer stacked pawns on "c" rank for the trade. 
However, my bishop is still attacking and I can develop a pawn to the front to apply extra pressure without mercy.
moves.4... d5: This does not alleviate the NIMZO ATTACK. It can develop rapidly to complicate White.
moves.5. Bd3: I want c7 to c5 anyway. It is the NIMZO ATTACK. Nothing here is changing this.
moves.5... c5: Now the Classical NIMZO ATTACK is in operation with my c5.
moves.6. Nge2: He is clearing and defending house here; but the NIMZO ATTACK is on schedule.
moves.6... cxd4: His knight at c3 is useless.
moves.7. exd4: A forthright pawn trade to diminish the NIMZO ATTACK.
moves.7... dxc4: It results in an isolated pawn for white
moves.9... Nc6: I am developing whilst seeing I may have to move my knight that just JUMPED out.
moves.10. a3: Pressuring my bishop to another place....
moves.10... Bd6: If he wants to continue pushing my bishop let him do so...
moves.12... Ng4+: under attack by an unlikely piece while his bishop is out for grab.
moves.13. Kg3: So I am ready to grab it.
moves.14. f4: Separating my Queen necessarily for now...
moves.15. f5: An advance I can handle with a pawn...
moves.15... exf5: I have to use it...and defend the posted knight.
moves.16. Nf4: I am thinking another pin is in the make...
moves.17. Nb5: White is trying to unpin the pin...
moves.18. d5: White pushes a "passed pawn" to threaten...
moves.18... Nce5: I move my knight forward with my forward deployed knight. Together they are a lock.
moves.19. Be2: In the lock the knights are fine. This move entices me to do what knights are famous for....
moves.19... Ne3: A fork between two more valuable pieces.
moves.20. Qc1: He doesn't want to lose his queen for the rook. Should I take the rook?
moves.20... Nxf1+: No better thing to do no better move to make....
moves.21... g5: I am doing the King Side attack now...
moves.23. Qxf4: My King has an open next window to White's Queen but my pawn has served to block that next move before
moves.23... Ng6: I close the window and attack while my bishop on c1 is still there to defend.
moves.24. Qh6: An aggressive move made by a piece not in a position to really do much.
moves.25. Nc7: He wants that rook I never moved...
moves.25... Bd7: He can have it if he wants.
moves.27. Kf3: His knight is still hesitating from the Book of Second Hesitations....
